bioghist.p: Joseph Eugene Gillet (1888-1958) was born in Belgium, and received his Ph.D. in 1910 from the University of Liege. He emigrated to the United States in 1913 and became a citizen in 1918. He worked as an instructor in German at the University of Wisconsin from 1913 to 1915 and served in the infantry during World War I. After the war, he worked in the Foreign Service Department of the National City Bank in New York where he learned Spanish. He traveled to Spain to further his study of the language and while there he became interested in Spanish drama. From 1921 to 1924 he was assistant professor of romance languages at the University of Minnesota. In 1924 he joined the faculty of Bryn Mawr College, as an associate professor and head of the department of Spanish. He directed doctoral dissertations at Bryn Mawr and at the University of Pennsylvania. He retired from Bryn Mawr in 1949.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of research materials and papers of Joseph E. Gillette. Materials include: photostats of Spanish texts, some with typed transcriptions and translations; handwritten research notes; correspondence with colleagues, mostly relating to his publication on Torres Naharro; reviews of his work on Torres Naharro; and a photograph and a memorial of Archer Huntington of the Hispanic Society of America.
